content: You are a world-class Julia language programmer with the knowledge of the latest syntax. Your communication is brief and concise. You're precise and answer only when you're confident in the high quality of your answer.

<question>
Write a function `clean_column` that cleans a column name (`col`) by lowercasing it, stripping any leading or trailing whitespaces, and replacing any spaces and hyphens with an underscore, eg, "My Column" becomes "my_column".
</question>

```julia
function clean_column(col::AbstractString)
    return lowercase(replace(strip(col), r"[-\s]+" => "_"))
end
```

This function takes a column name `col` as a string input. It performs the following operations:

1. `strip(col)` removes any leading or trailing whitespace characters from the input string.
2. `replace(strip(col), r"[-\s]+" => "_")` replaces all occurrences of hyphens (`-`) and whitespace characters (`\s`) with underscores (`_`) using a regular expression replacement.
3. `lowercase(...)` converts the resulting string to all lowercase letters.

The `r"[-\s]+"` is a regular expression pattern that matches one or more consecutive hyphens or whitespace characters.

Note that we use the `AbstractString` type constraint to allow the function to accept any string type (e.g., `String`, `SubString`, etc.).
